questions.answerC: Solid yellow
questions.explanation: White lines separate traffic lanes traveling in the same direction. You may cross broken white lines to pass, as long as the passing lane is clear.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: Before entering a roundabout, you must slow down and yield to:
questions.answerC: Pedestrians in the roundabout.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and vehicles that are already in the roundabout.

questions.question: To let other drivers know that you intend to turn, signal at least ____ feet in advance.
questions.explanation: Signal your intention to turn at least 100 feet before the point where you plan to change directions. This allows other drivers time to safely react to your movements.

questions.question: A red traffic signal light means that you must:
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection.
questions.explanation: A red traffic light means that you must stop before entering the intersection. You must at any stop line and before entering any crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Dangerous curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers to be extra careful when the pavement is wet because the road may become slippery, making vehicles more difficult to control.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: When driving on the interstate, slower traffic should:
questions.answerC: Keep to the left.
questions.explanation: On an interstate highway, slow traffic should keep to the right. The left lane is intended for use by faster-moving vehicles to pass slower-moving vehicles.

questions.question: Drivers who refuse to submit to chemical testing when requested to do so by an officer will lose their license for:
questions.answerC: One year.
questions.explanation: Nebraska has an Implied Consent Law. This means that by driving in the state, you have agreed to undergo a chemical test if asked to do so by a law enforcement officer. If you refuse to submit to such a test, your license can be administratively revoked for one year.

questions.question: What is the penalty for fleeing to avoid arrest?
questions.answerA: The driver can be charged with a misdemeanor or felony offense.
questions.answerB: The driver could have their operator's license revoked.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Fleeing from a law enforcement officer to avoid arrest or citation for a misdemeanor or ordinance violation is itself a misdemeanor. Fleeing from a law enforcement officer to avoid arrest or citation for a felony is itself a felony. In either case, the driver's license may be revoked.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
questions.answerC: Warning.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs are used to warn drivers of special conditions or hazards ahead. They are typically yellow or orange in color.

questions.question: When driving on major highways:
questions.answerC: Be ready to react to road hazards.
questions.explanation: It is important to stay alert on highways and be ready to react to unexpected hazards. To avoid "highway hypnosis," you should avoid looking at any one thing for more than a few seconds.

questions.question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver.
questions.answerB: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop at a crosswalk to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian already in the intersection. You may carefully proceed if your lane is completely clear.

questions.question: Headlights must be used:
questions.answerC: After 8 p.m. and before 7 a.m.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's headlights must be activated between sunset and sunrise. Use headlights any time you are driving under conditions that lower visibility.

questions.question: Fines for speeding are tripled in work and school zones.
questions.explanation: Fines for moving traffic violations are doubled in work zones where workers are present, as well as in school zones during indicated hours. Always drive with caution when near children, workers, and other pedestrians.

questions.question: A pentagon-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerC: School zone or school crossing sign.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign is used to alert drivers to a school zone. Some pentagonal signs specifically indicate crosswalks within school zones where children or other pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: Your following distance when driving behind a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Be the same as it would be if following any other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase.
questions.explanation: When following a motorcycle, allow a greater following distance than you would when following any other vehicle. Motorcycles are able to stop and turn more quickly than larger vehicles and a driver following a motorcyclist needs time to react to their quick movements.

questions.question: When you want to leave the interstate, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal and move into the proper lane a mile or more before your desired exit.
questions.answerB: Slow to 45 miles per hour before reaching your desired exit.
questions.answerC: Signal and slow down 50 to 100 feet before entering the exit ramp.
questions.explanation: When you want to leave the interstate, plan ahead and watch for exit signs. Make sure you are in the correct lane at least a mile before making the exit. Do not slow down until after you have moved into the deceleration lane.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: When arriving to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as vehicles to your right and left, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your left.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Wait until there are no vehicles at the intersection before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that is not controlled by signs or signals, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. Drivers should then proceed in the order that they arrive to the intersection.

questions.question: Never park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerC: 15 feet
questions.explanation: Parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant is prohibited. Only park where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are usually ____ and should always be obeyed.
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs regulate the movement of traffic. They are usually white with black markings and must always be obeyed by motorists.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be alert to crossing pedestrians.

questions.question: It is unlawful to drive alongside a motorcycle in the same lane.
questions.explanation: You must never attempt to share a lane with a motorcyclist, even if it looks like there is enough room to do so. Motorcyclists need to have a full lane width to be able to maneuver safely.

questions.question: If your turn signals fail, you should use ____ to indicate that you are turning.
questions.answerC: Hand signals
questions.explanation: If your vehicle's turn signals do not work, you should use hand signals to indicate when you intend to change direction.

questions.question: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02 percent:
questions.answerA: Won't have any effect on your driving.
questions.answerB: Won't put other drivers at risk.
questions.answerC: Will double your chances of having an accident.
questions.explanation: Every 0.02 percent increase in blood alcohol concentration nearly doubles a driver's risk of being in a fatal crash.

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Does not increase the chance of a crash.
questions.answerB: Increases your ability to react to a hazard.
questions.answerC: Often leads to high-risk decision-making.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: Nebraska's speed law requires you drive:
questions.answerB: Five miles per hour above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed that is reasonable and safe under existing conditions.
questions.explanation: Nebraska's speed law requires driving at a speed that is reasonable and safe under existing conditions, within the posted speed limit. Reduce your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: It is very foggy. You should slow down and:
questions.answerB: Turn your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights to their low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: If you are feeling fatigued while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Increase the volume of your radio.
questions.answerC: Find a safe parking area to take a short nap.
questions.explanation: When driving, watch for warning signs of fatigue. You are too tired to drive safely if you are struggling to keep your eyes open, drifting from your lane, or turning up the radio and rolling down your windows to keep yourself awake. If you notice these signs, it is a good idea to find a safe place to park so you can refresh yourself with a short nap.

questions.question: Worn or bald tires:
questions.answerC: Can increase your stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Worn or bald tires can increase your stopping distance and make turning more difficult. Tires without adequate tread also increase the risk of hydroplaning.

questions.question: When approaching snow removal equipment, you should:
questions.answerB: Be aware of flying sand and chunks of ice and snow.
questions.answerC: Maintain a following distance of 100 feet.
questions.explanation: Maintain a following distance of 100 feet from snow removal equipment or other maintenance vehicles working on roadways, except to pass. Around such equipment, flying sand and chunks of ice and snow may damage surrounding vehicles. Snow removal equipment on the roadway may result in restricted visibility due to clouds of snow forming from the moving plows.

questions.question: What is the color of warning signs specific to pedestrians, bicycles, playgrounds, schools, and school buses?
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.explanation: Yellow-green signs are warning signs specific to pedestrians, bicycles, playgrounds, schools, and school buses. Be especially alert to pedestrians and children when near one of these signs.

questions.question: The best thing to do if you become tired while driving is to:
questions.answerA: Stop to rest or change drivers.
questions.answerC: Open a window.
questions.explanation: If you become tired while driving, it is best to stop to rest or change drivers. Being tired dulls your mind and slows down your reactions, making driving hazardous.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection that has a stop sign but no painted crosswalk, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop your vehicle inside the unmarked crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Stop before entering the unmarked crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign. It does not matter if you are in the crosswalk or not.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop before entering the crosswalk. The crosswalk may be marked or unmarked.

questions.question: It is unlawful to:
questions.answerA: Pass in any marked no passing zone.
questions.answerB: Pass within 300 feet of a railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where it is unlawful for drivers to pass. Passing is prohibited within 100 feet of a railroad crossing, within 100 feet of an intersection, and within any other designated no passing zone.

questions.question: Broken yellow lines are used on streets and highways to:
questions.answerB: Separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines on the pavement indicate that passing is permitted when safe.

questions.question: When you drive through a construction zone, you should:
questions.answerC: Pass the construction zone carefully and not “rubberneck."
questions.explanation: To avoid contributing to chronic traffic congestion, you should not "rubberneck." That is, you should not slow down to look at out-of-the-ordinary things.

questions.question: The most frequent cause of motorcycle accidents is:
questions.answerA: The driver of a passenger vehicle failing to yield the right-of-way and making a left turn in front of an oncoming motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Inadequate road conditions.
questions.explanation: Approximately one-third of all motorcycle crashes involve a second motor vehicle. Many motorcycle accidents are caused by the driver of a passenger vehicle turning left in front of an oncoming motorcycle instead of properly yielding the right-of-way.

questions.question: If you become drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerC: Take some caffeine pills.
questions.explanation: If you start to feel tired while driving, drive to the first available rest stop or service area to take a break, nap, stretch, or change drivers. You should not rely on caffeine pills or energy drinks, as these are not a replacement for rest and may make your driving even more dangerous.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: When you are behind a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Be ready to use your horn.
questions.answerC: Allow a larger following distance.
questions.explanation: When following a motorcyclist, allow for at least a three- to four-second following distance. Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist should fall, you need extra distance to avoid the rider. The chances of a fall are greatest on wet and icy roads, gravel roads, and metal surfaces such as bridges, gratings, and streetcar or railroad tracks.

questions.question: As you approach the top of a hill, you should:
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: You may not know what is on the other side of a hill or just around a curve, even if you have driven the road many times. If a vehicle is stalled just out of sight on the roadway, you must be able to stop. Whenever you come to a hill or curve, adjust your speed so you can stop if necessary.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: The highway ahead curves only to the right.
questions.answerB: The highway ahead turns sharply to the right.
questions.answerC: The highway ahead curves to the right and then to the left.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead curves to the left and then to the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits U-turns. Do not make a U-turn where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When approaching a stopped school bus from the opposite side of a highway that is divided by a median, you must stop.
questions.explanation: It is generally unlawful to pass a school bus that has its stop lights on and stop arm extended. However, you do not need to stop when the bus is on the opposite side of a roadway divided by a median.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: Before returning to your original lane after passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: See both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights.
questions.explanation: When passing is permitted, look for both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Only then may you safely return to your original lane.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerC: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the pedestrian cross.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop whenever you see pedestrians walking on or crossing the roadway. Be particularly careful where children are present. Always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing in a crosswalk.

questions.question: When you want to change lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Move into another lane while within an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: You should never change lanes within an intersection. Before changing lanes, always look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Be alert to other drivers moving into the same lane.

questions.question: Only ____ can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time can remove alcohol and its impairing effects from the body.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerC: A right turn is permitted on a green arrow only.
questions.explanation: Some warning signs have a fluorescent yellow-green background. These signs warn of upcoming conditions, including roads with curves and sharp turns.

questions.question: Failure to secure child passengers in a safety belt or child safety seat is punishable by:
questions.answerA: A fine and one point assessed against the driver.
questions.answerB: Two points assessed against the driver.
questions.answerC: Two points and court costs assessed against the driver.
questions.explanation: Children under age 18 must be secured in a safety belt or child safety seat when riding in a motor vehicle. If cited for violation of this requirement, a driver may be fined $25 (plus court costs) and incur one point on their driving record.

questions.question: All children under age 18 are required to ride:
questions.answerA: In the back seat of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: In the front seat of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Secured in a safety belt or child safety seat.
questions.explanation: Children under age 18 are required to be secured in a safety belt or child safety seat when in a moving vehicle.

questions.question: At dusk or on overcast days, you should:
questions.answerC: Not turn on any vehicle lights.
questions.explanation: At dusk or on overcast days, you must turn on your headlights. Dim your lights to their low beam setting when within 1,000 feet of an approaching vehicle and when within 500 feet of a vehicle that you are following. When driving in poor weather, always use your low beams.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: Enter a roundabout:
questions.answerA: Only when there is an adequate gap in traffic.
questions.answerB: Immediately, as traffic entering a roundabout always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: After coming to a complete stop and looking both ways.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to traffic that is already in the circle. Enter when there is a safe gap in traffic.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow light indicates that you should be alert and proceed with caution. Slow down when approaching a flashing yellow traffic signal.

questions.question: What happens if you drink alcohol while taking prescription or over-the-counter medicine?
questions.answerA: The medicine reduces the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The alcohol will help the medicine cure a cold.
questions.answerC: The combination could multiply the effects of the alcohol or medicine.
questions.answerD: There is no effect because they are different substances.
questions.explanation: Consuming alcohol and other drugs together can increase the impairing effects of both. For example, having one drink while you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as much as several drinks would when being consumed separately from any medications.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection controlled by a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers in the proper lane may:
questions.answerA: Proceed in the direction of the arrow after coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Proceed in the direction of the arrow after yielding to approaching traffic and/or pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Proceed in the direction of the arrow while maintaining their speed because they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped until the light turns green.
questions.explanation: If you are in a lane corresponding to a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, you should proceed in the direction indicated by the arrow after yielding to approaching traffic and/or pedestrians.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: Using a handheld wireless communication device to read, type, or send written communication while operating a motor vehicle is:
questions.answerB: A secondary offense carrying a fine between $50 and $100.
questions.answerC: A secondary offense carrying a fine between $200 and $500.
questions.answerD: Not a traffic violation in Nebraska.
questions.explanation: It is a secondary offense to use a handheld wireless communication device to read, type, or send written communication while operating a motor vehicle. Violation of this law carries a fine between $200 and $500.

questions.question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals:
questions.answerA: Only when pulling away from the curb.
questions.answerB: When pulling next to, but not away from, the curb.
questions.answerC: When pulling next to or away from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers should signal when pulling next to a curb or away from a curb.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following substances can affect the ability to drive?
questions.answerB: Cough syrups and cold tablets containing codeine or antihistamines.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: A number of drugs can impair your ability to drive, including depressant medications like tranquilizers and sedatives; over-the-counter cough syrups, cold tablets, and allergy medications (which may contain impairing substances like alcohol, codeine, or antihistamines); and illegal drugs.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: You reach an intersection with stop signs on all four corners at the same time as the driver on your left. Who has the right-of-way?
questions.answerA: The driver on your left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Whoever is signaling to make a turn has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that has stop signs on all corners, the vehicle to the right has the right-of-way.

questions.question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

questions.question: Certain highway signs contain information about hazardous conditions. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Warning signs advise drivers of potentially hazardous conditions. For your own safety, obey warning signs. Disregarding the information provided by a warning sign may result in an accident due to your negligence.

questions.question: If you have a sudden tire blowout:
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly goes flat while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle moving straight. Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching the end of a divided highway.
questions.answerB: You are approaching the beginning of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: The road will be slippery ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. Keep to the right of the median divider.

questions.question: There is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Slow down as you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where traffic is not controlled by traffic signal lights, drivers are required to yield the right-of-way to pedestrians within any crosswalk, marked or unmarked. Even if there is no crosswalk, yield to the pedestrian.

questions.question: Accumulating 12 points against your license in a two-year period will result in an automatic revocation of your driver license for ____ months.
questions.answerC: Nine
questions.explanation: Accumulating 12 violation points in a two-year period will lead to the automatic revocation of an operator's license for six months.

questions.question: When completing an emergency roadside stop, it is not necessary to put on your parking brake.
questions.explanation: Set your parking brake when making an emergency roadside stop. Turn on your emergency flashers to alert other drivers to your presence.

questions.question: When passing on the left of a vehicle, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the front of the vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on its left, you may move back into the right lane when the headlights of the passed vehicle can be seen in your rearview mirror. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Leave the front wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that has a curb, your wheels should be turned away from the curb. When parking uphill on a street without a curb or when parking downhill, your wheels should be turned toward the curb or edge of the road.

questions.question: While driving on a roadway with a single broken white centerline:
questions.answerA: You must stay within your lane.
questions.answerB: You may cross the centerline to change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes only from the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines between lanes indicate that the lanes are traveling in the same direction. Broken white line markings indicate that it is legal to pass another vehicle when safe.

questions.question: When approaching a disabled pedestrian using a guide dog, white cane, or other assistive device, a driver should yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: A pedestrian with a disability who is utilizing a guide dog, a white cane, a wheelchair, or another assistive device, whether on a sidewalk or roadway, has the right-of-way and is granted the same rights as any other pedestrian.

questions.question: The minimum legal driving speed when traveling on the interstate is:
questions.answerC: 60 mph.
questions.explanation: The minimum speed limit on interstate highways in Nebraska is 40 miles per hour. Only drive under the minimum speed limit if conditions require it.

questions.question: Failure to secure children under age six in a federally-approved child safety seat is a traffic violation punishable by a $25 fine and one point assessed against the driver.
questions.explanation: Children up to age six must be properly secured in a federally-approved child safety seat when in a moving vehicle. Violation of this law is punishable by a fine of $25 (plus court costs) and the assessment of one point on the operating driver's record.

questions.question: Persons who leave the scene of a motor vehicle crash may have their driver license revoked for up to ____ upon conviction.
questions.answerC: Nine months
questions.explanation: Conviction of leaving the scene of a crash may result in license revocation for one year.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels facing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that does not have a curb, your front wheels should be turned to the right (toward the edge of the road). This will ensure that the vehicle will roll off of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rumble strips?
questions.answerA: They alert drivers to potential tire problems.
questions.answerB: They test a vehicle's shock absorbers.
questions.answerC: Through vibration and sound, they alert inattentive drivers to the fact that their vehicles have left the travel lane.
questions.explanation: Rumble strips create noise and vibrations to warn drowsy or inattentive drivers that they are straying off of the road or are approaching a stop sign or signal.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should not:
questions.answerC: Press your head against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Brace yourself by pressing against the back of your seat and putting your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: A yellow light that flashes on and off means:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for other vehicles, then go if there is no traffic.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait for a green light.
questions.answerC: Speed up to clear the intersection quickly.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers should slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to slow down.
questions.answerB: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and, if necessary, yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This type of triangular sign means drivers must yield. You must slow down as you come to an intersection marked with this sign and be prepared to stop. Let any other vehicles, bicyclists, or pedestrians pass safely before you proceed.

questions.question: If you need to slow down while driving on a slippery road, the first thing you should do is:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Apply your parking brake.
questions.explanation: To slow down on a slippery road, you should first take your foot off the gas pedal. If you need to slow down even more, gently apply a slow, steady pressure to your brake pedal.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: The maximum posted speed limit should be driven only:
questions.answerC: Under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. It is safest to drive at the same speed as surrounding traffic, up to the maximum speed limit. Maintaining a safe speed at all times is a responsibility shared by all motorists.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in rain, snow, sleet, or fog. High beam headlights in adverse weather conditions lower visibility by reflecting off the precipitation and back into the driver's eyes.

questions.question: When parking uphill on a hill or incline with a curb:
questions.answerA: Turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn your front wheels slightly to the right.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb.
questions.explanation: To keep your vehicle from rolling into traffic when parked facing uphill, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. If you are parking uphill on a street that has no curb, turn the wheels sharply toward the edge of the road.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on a non-hard surface county road is:
questions.answerC: 50 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: The speed limit on a county road without a hard surface is ordinarily 50 miles per hour. If another speed limit is posted, follow the posted limit.

questions.question: When approaching a roundabout:
questions.answerB: Enter the circle without yielding, as you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Yield to traffic already within the roundabout.
questions.answerD: Wait to enter until all other traffic has exited the roundabout.
questions.explanation: Before entering a roundabout, yield to all vehicles that are already within the roundabout. Traffic will be moving in a counterclockwise direction and will be approaching on your left.

questions.question: When driving under snowy or icy conditions, it is safe to use your cruise control as long as your speed is reduced.
questions.explanation: You should not use cruise control when driving on snowy or icy roads. Your tires may lose contact with the road and you will no longer have control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Fines for speeding are ____ in work zones.
questions.answerC: Tripled
questions.explanation: Fines for moving traffic violations are doubled in work zones where workers are present, as well as in school zones during indicated hours. Always drive with caution when near children, workers, and other pedestrians.

questions.question: At a four-way stop, the driver on the right should insist on the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Never insist on having the right-of-way. Always yield your legal right-of-way when it can prevent an accident.

questions.question: The consumption of alcohol while taking drugs can:
questions.answerA: Decrease the effects of the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerB: Increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerC: Help cure your illness.
questions.explanation: The combination of alcohol and drugs, in some cases, can increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol. It can be unsafe to drive after consuming either alcohol or drugs and is even more dangerous after combining them.

questions.question: In Nebraska, the blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for drivers under the age of 21 is:
questions.answerC: 0.1 percent.
questions.explanation: In Nebraska, it is unlawful for people under the legal drinking age of 21 to operate a motor vehicle with a BAC of 0.02 percent or higher.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are:
questions.answerC: White.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs inform drivers of specific laws that must be obeyed. Displayed laws may be about traffic direction, lane use, turning, speed, parking, or special situations. Regulatory signs are commonly white squares or rectangles with black, red, or green letters or symbols.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning signal. Use caution when driving near railroad tracks.

questions.question: If you have an argument with another person and you are angry, you should:
questions.answerA: Loudly play the radio while driving so you won’t think about your argument.
questions.answerB: Take a few minutes to cool off before driving.
questions.answerC: Drive on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.explanation: Your emotions affect your ability to drive safely. If you are overly angry, excited, afraid, worried, or depressed, you should give yourself time to calm down before operating a vehicle. You need to be able to mentally focus on driving without thinking about the things that made you upset.

questions.question: It is unlawful to:
questions.answerA: Pass a school bus that is using its flashing red lights and has its stop arm extended.
questions.answerB: Pass within 100 feet of any intersection.
questions.answerC: Pass within 100 feet of any railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: There are a number of situations where it is unlawful for drivers to pass. Drivers may not pass a school bus that is loading or unloading children. Passing is prohibited within 100 feet of a railroad crossing, within 100 feet of an intersection, and within any other designated no passing zone.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should check your side mirrors and look over your shoulder to make sure it is safe to proceed.

questions.question: It is important to frequently check the traffic behind you when:
questions.answerC: Slowing down.
questions.explanation: Check the traffic behind your vehicle no less than once every 10 seconds. It is important to know what surrounding traffic is doing while you are changing lanes, backing up, slowing down, or driving down steep hills.

questions.question: Never drive a vehicle through, around, or under any railroad gate or barrier.
questions.explanation: Never drive through, around, or under gates or barriers at a railroad crossing. It is illegal and very dangerous.

questions.question: When driving in fog or mist, never put your headlights on the high beam setting because:
questions.answerA: The light will reflect back into your eyes.
questions.answerB: Approaching vehicles might not see you.
questions.answerC: Vehicles behind you may follow too closely.
questions.explanation: In foggy or misty conditions, you should not use your headlights on their high beam setting because the light will be reflected back into your eyes.

questions.question: If bad weather makes it difficult for you to see clearly, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get off the road quickly.
questions.answerB: Drive in the lane closest to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When it is difficult to see due to darkness or poor weather, increase your following distance. This will give you more time to react to hazards that you may not see in advance.

questions.question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
questions.answerC: Mileage information, such as distances to specific locations.
questions.explanation: Blue signs on the roadway are service signs. They are used to provide information about motorist services, such as upcoming rest areas, food options, or nearby hospitals.

questions.question: Children up to age ____ are prohibited from riding in cargo areas.
questions.explanation: Children up to age 18 are prohibited from riding in the cargo area of a vehicle. They must be safely secured in a safety belt or child safety seat while in a moving vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign marks the presence of a crosswalk. Be alert to any pedestrians that may be crossing the roadway.

questions.question: A driver that operates a vehicle on Nebraska roadways has already agreed to submit to a chemical test when requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: Nebraska has an Implied Consent Law. This means that by driving a vehicle in the state, you give your consent to undergo chemical testing if requested to do so by an officer.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: A major factor contributing to crashes resulting in death and/or serious injury is:
questions.answerA: Drivers transporting more than one child at a time.
questions.answerB: Drivers driving while under the influence of alcohol or other drugs.
questions.answerC: Drivers making frequent stops to rest on long trips.
questions.explanation: It is unlawful to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or other drugs. In Nebraska, driving under the influence is a major factor contributing to crashes resulting in death and/or serious injury.

questions.question: If a traffic signal is not working and no officer is in place to direct traffic, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Treat the intersection as if it is controlled by yield signs.
questions.answerB: Treat the intersection as an all-way stop.
questions.answerC: Allow drivers on major streets to have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Continue through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: If a traffic signal is not working and no officer is present to direct traffic, treat the intersection the same as you would treat an all-way stop. Be prepared to yield your legal right-of-way to avoid any traffic accidents.

questions.question: If your vehicle starts to lose traction because of water on the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive at a constant speed to gain better traction.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly to prevent your vehicle from sliding.
questions.answerC: Slow down gradually and not apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving in heavy rain at speeds as low as 30 mph, your tires may lose all contact with the road and instead ride up on a layer of water above the surface of the road. This is called "hydroplaning." If your vehicle starts to hydroplane, slow down gradually and do not apply the brakes.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a residential district is:
questions.answerC: 30 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: The speed limit in a residential district is ordinarily 25 miles per hour. If another speed limit is posted, follow the posted limit.

questions.question: It is dangerous to follow a motorcycle too closely because:
questions.answerA: They do not follow the same rules as motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle can stop much faster than a standard vehicle.
questions.answerC: They brake more slowly than motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist makes a mistake, you need to have enough time and space to avoid a crash.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross the street after the "Don't Walk" signal begins to flash. The pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green. You should:
questions.answerA: Proceed if you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Proceed if the pedestrian is not in your lane.
questions.answerC: Wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a green light, you must give the right-of-way to any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. If a pedestrian begins crossing the street after the traffic signal light starts flashing, wait until they have crossed the street before proceeding.

questions.question: A good rule to remember for passing is:
questions.answerA: Pass on the right whenever possible.
questions.answerB: Drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
questions.answerC: Try to get to the front of any slow-moving traffic so that you can see better.
questions.answerD: Always flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your intentions.
questions.explanation: Each time you pass another vehicle, there is an increased chance for a collision. If you are moving faster than surrounding traffic, you will have to continue passing others. Drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit, and pass only as needed.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
questions.answerA: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: A driver must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian within a crosswalk. The driver should wait until the intersection is clear to proceed.

questions.question: If involved in a minor crash that causes no injuries and very little damage, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Leave the vehicles in the traffic lane where they were impacted and wait for law enforcement to arrive.
questions.answerB: Place two orange traffic cones at intervals of 50 and 100 feet behind the vehicles.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicles out of the travel lanes and onto the nearest shoulder.
questions.answerD: Signal to surrounding drivers by opening the trunks and hoods of all vehicles involved in the crash.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a minor crash on an interstate or freeway, you must move your vehicle out of the travel lanes and onto the nearest shoulder. If your vehicle cannot be driven to the shoulder, it may be pushed to the shoulder by law enforcement. Do not move individuals who are injured.

questions.question: It is unlawful to operate a motor vehicle on any public roadway when the vehicle is equipped with a television screen that is visible to the driver.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a vehicle that is equipped with a television screen that is visible to the driver.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic and pedestrians. Once the intersection is clear and applicable signals allow, you may complete the turn.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: When operating a motor vehicle, it is a secondary offense to use a handheld wireless communication device:
questions.answerA: To read, type, or send written communication.
questions.answerC: As a GPS navigation device.
questions.explanation: It is a secondary offense to use a handheld wireless communication device to read, type, or send written communication while operating a motor vehicle. Violation of this law will result in a fine ranging from $200 to $500.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a business district is:
questions.answerC: 30 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: The speed limit in a business district is ordinarily 20 miles per hour. If another speed limit is posted, follow the posted limit.

questions.question: Which of the following factors affect an individual's absorption of alcohol?
questions.answerC: Intelligence
questions.explanation: Factors affecting a person's absorption of alcohol include the person's weight, their biological sex, the amount of food in their digestive tract, and the number of alcoholic beverages they have consumed. The only thing to do to remove alcohol from a person's system is to wait.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. They should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid brake damage or collision.

questions.question: Never park a vehicle:
questions.answerA: In front of a public or private driveway.
questions.answerB: Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection.
questions.answerC: Within 30 feet of any flashing signal located on the side of the roadway.
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where it is prohibited to stop or park your vehicle. Among these locations are in front of a public or private driveway; within 20 feet of a crosswalk; and within 30 feet of any stop sign, flashing signal, yield sign, or other traffic control device located on the side of the roadway.

questions.question: When a stop is required at an intersection and no markings appear to indicate a stop line or crosswalk, a driver:
questions.answerB: Is required to slow down to make sure crossing traffic is clear.
questions.answerC: Should stop only at a place where they can see at least 200 feet on either side, even if they have to enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.answerD: Should stop where they have a clear view of approaching traffic before they enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.explanation: If there is no stop line or crosswalk, you should stop at the point nearest to the intersecting roadway where you can get a view of approaching traffic. You should not enter the intersecting roadway to gain a better view.

questions.question: When driving on the interstate, you should use the left lane:
questions.answerB: To overtake or pass another vehicle.
questions.answerC: Before crossing the median.
questions.explanation: On an interstate highway, you should stay in the right lane unless you are passing another vehicle. You should not exceed the speed limit when passing.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Stare directly in front of their car.
questions.answerB: Only focus on the middle of the road.
questions.answerC: Watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car.
questions.explanation: A driver should watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car. To be a good driver, you must know what is happening all around your vehicle.

questions.question: At an intersection with a stop sign, you should stop and:
questions.answerA: Check your rearview mirror for cars tailgating.
questions.answerB: Move when the vehicle ahead of you moves.
questions.answerC: Look right first, then left, then right again.
questions.answerD: Look left first, then right, then left again.
questions.explanation: When stopped at an intersection, you should first look to your left, as vehicles coming from the left are closer to you than vehicles coming from the right. Look to your right, then look to your left again, in case there are any vehicles coming from that direction that you did not see at first glance.

questions.question: If a flagger is directing traffic in a construction zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the flagger.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the flagger's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the flagger is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow the laws that would be in place if the area was not under construction.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, flagger, or law enforcement officer. Failure to do so is illegal and is dangerous to those working in construction zones.

questions.question: To help others see you when daylight begins to fade, you should use your:
questions.answerC: Emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: As daylight begins to fade, turn on your low beams to help others see you. Only use your high beam headlights in an open area where no other drivers are present.

questions.question: While driving on the interstate, you see vehicles on the entrance ramp to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to beat the vehicles that are on the entrance ramp.
questions.answerC: Merge left to allow them space for a smooth, safe entry.
questions.explanation: When you are driving on the interstate and see vehicles on an entrance ramp to your right, you should signal and move to the left to allow them a smooth and safe entry. If it is unsafe to merge left, adjust your speed to help the incoming traffic merge.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerC: Be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: When you see any signs indicating a nearby railroad crossing, you should slow down, look for a train, and be ready to stop. If the red warning lights are flashing or the gate is down, you must stop 15 to 50 feet before the railroad tracks. Do not try to go around the gate.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of of an approaching traffic signal.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the surface of the road. To prevent hydroplaning in rainy weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, you should lower your speed to reduce the risk of hydroplaning. Driving too fast may cause your tires to ride up on the water and lose contact with the surface of the road, making it very difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: Braking distance is affected by:
questions.answerA: The speed your vehicle is traveling.
questions.answerB: The condition of your brakes and tires.
questions.answerC: The condition of the pavement.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect braking distance include how fast your vehicle is traveling, the condition of your brakes and tires, and the condition of the pavement.

questions.question: Flashing arrow panels used in work zones:
questions.answerA: Indicate where drivers must pull onto the shoulder of the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Guide drivers into certain traffic lanes and inform them that part of the upcoming roadway is closed.
questions.answerC: Are only used on the Interstate Highway System.
questions.explanation: Large flashing arrow panels may be used in work zones to guide drivers into certain traffic lanes and to inform them that part of the upcoming roadway is closed. Drivers should follow all provided instructions in a work zone.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that traffic in the lane next to the broken line may cross the line to pass, while traffic in the lane next to the solid line may not.

questions.question: When another vehicle is passing your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Pull your vehicle as far to the right as possible without leaving the pavement.
questions.answerB: Stay in your lane and maintain your speed, unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: When being passed, stay in your lane and maintain your speed, except in an emergency. In the case of an emergency, speed up, slow down, or leave the road as necessary to prevent a crash.

questions.question: Bicyclists have all the same rights and responsibilities as drivers of motor vehicles and must obey all traffic laws.
questions.explanation: Under Nebraska law, a bicyclist has the same rights and responsibilities as a motorist and must obey all traffic laws. Drivers of motor vehicles should respect a bicyclist's right to share the roadway.

questions.question: If you want to get off the freeway but you have missed your exit, you should:
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn through the median.
questions.answerC: Pull onto the shoulder and back your car to the exit.
questions.answerD: Flag down a police officer for an escort back to your exit.
questions.explanation: If you miss your exit, you should take the next exit. Do not stop or back up on the highway, swerve across multiple lanes to try to make the exit at the last second, or cross over the median to turn around. All of these maneuvers are illegal and extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Stop until the lights stop flashing.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and pass cautiously.
questions.explanation: The flashing overhead lights and stop arm on a school bus will be activated when the bus is stopped to load or unload students. If approaching a bus using these signals, you may not proceed until the red lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm has been retracted. Never pass a school bus that is dropping off or picking up students.

questions.question: Barricades, vertical panels, drums, and cones are most commonly used to guide drivers safely through a work zone.
questions.explanation: Barricades, vertical panels, drums, and cones are most commonly used to guide drivers safely through work zones. Drivers should use caution when passing through a work zone.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline means that:
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline means that a driver may cross the centerline to pass another vehicle on the left as long as there is no oncoming traffic. Drivers should never cross a solid yellow centerline in order to pass.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses have air brakes and cannot stop as quickly as smaller vehicles can.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher rate of speed than smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: While automobiles have hydraulic brakes, large trucks and buses have air brakes. Air brakes do not operate as quickly as hydraulic brakes, so large trucks and buses cannot stop as quickly as smaller vehicles can.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Turn around.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a roundabout is ahead. Enter a roundabout at a low speed and yield to existing traffic.

questions.question: Turning left at a red light is never permitted.
questions.explanation: Unless prohibited by a sign, drivers may turn left on a solid red light from a one-way street onto another one-way street. There are no other situations in which a driver may turn left when stopped at a solid red traffic light.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait until it is safe to do so, then gradually re-enter the roadway.
questions.answerB: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, do not attempt to turn back onto the roadway immediately. Instead, reduce your speed, check traffic, and gradually turn back onto the roadway when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: After passing a vehicle, it is safe to return to your driving lane when:
questions.answerA: The driver you passed signals for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: You signal your intention for three seconds.
questions.answerC: You see the headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to your driving lane, be sure you are not dangerously close to the vehicle you have just passed. One way to do this is to look for the vehicle in your inside rearview mirror. When you can see both headlights in your rearview mirror, you may have enough room to return to your driving lane.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver and lower visibility.

questions.question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
questions.answerA: Have a red background with green writing.
questions.answerB: Have an orange background with black writing.
questions.answerC: Have a yellow background with blue writing.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have orange backgrounds with black writing and/or symbols.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: School zone and crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign informs drivers that they are leaving a divided roadway and approaching a two-way highway.

questions.question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
questions.answerB: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: When following a small passenger car.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, or any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: This green arrow on a lane use control signal means:
questions.answerB: No traffic is allowed in this lane.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: You must merge into this lane.
questions.explanation: A steady downward green arrow over a traffic lane means you may use the lane indicated.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding funeral procession escort vehicles?
questions.answerA: They are classified as emergency vehicles.
questions.answerB: They are not considered emergency vehicles.
questions.answerC: They are considered emergency vehicles only when escorted by a police vehicle.
questions.explanation: Funeral procession escort vehicles are classified as emergency vehicles. Drivers are required to yield to funeral escort vehicles which are displaying proper audio or visual signals.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed.
